sen.j: 源 義家（みなもと の よしいえ）は、平安時代後期の武将で、河内源氏の源頼信の孫。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshiie was the busho (Japanese military commander) in the Heian Period and the grandson of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu of the Kawachi Genji (the Kawachi branch of the Minamoto clan).
MINAMOTO no Yoshiie was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Heian Period and the grandson of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu of the Kawachi Genji (the Kawachi branch of the Minamoto clan).
MINAMOTO no Yoshiie was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Heian period and the grandson of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu of the Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan).
sen.cmt: period小文字にしました。ハイフン補足、説明訂正しました。

sen.j: 八幡太郎義家（はちまんたろうよしいえ）という呼び名でも知られる。
sen.e: He was also known by his alias, Hachiman-taro-yoshiie.
He was also known by his alias, Hachiman-taro-yoshiie.
He was also known by his alias, Hachimantaro Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足。大文字にしました。

sen.j: 後に武家政権鎌倉幕府を開いた源頼朝、そして室町幕府の足利尊氏の祖先に当たることから後世に英雄視され、様々な逸話が生み出される。
sen.e: Since he was the ancestor of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) headed by bushi (warrior) and Takauji ASHIKAGA who founded the Muromachi bakufu, he was often portrayed as a hero by later generations and many anecdotes were made about him.

As the ancestor of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established the Kamakura bakufu (military govenment) and Takauji ASHIKAGA who founded the Muromachi bakufu, he was often portrayed as a hero by later generations and there are many anecdotes about him.
sen.cmt: "Since he was"→"As""Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun"→"military government"― less wordy. Maybe Shogunate is OK for "bakufu""headed by bushi (warrior)" erased"many anecdotes were made"→"there are many anecdotes"
sen.e: As the ancestor of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established the Kamakura bakufu (military government) and Takauji ASHIKAGA who founded the Muromachi bakufu, he was often portrayed as a hero by later generations and there are many anecdotes about him.

sen.j: 比叡山等の強訴の頻発に際し、その鎮圧や白河天皇の行幸の護衛に活躍するが、陸奥国守となったとき、清原氏の内紛に介入して後三年の役を起こし、朝廷に事後承認を求めるが、朝廷は「私戦」として官符を下さなかった。
sen.e: He actively participated as the guard for the Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visits, suppressed rebelling Mount Hiei monks, but when he became Mutsu-kokushu (the Lord of Mutsu province), he interfered in the internal conflict of the Kiyohara clan and triggered the Later Three Years' War and sought the official post-war consent from the imperial court but was denied as "a private feud."

He served as a guard for the Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visits and suppressed rebelling Mount Hiei monks, but after becoming Mutsu-kokushu (the Lord of Mutsu Province), he interfered in the internal conflict of the Kiyohara clan, triggering the Later Three Years' War which, although he sought official post-war consent, was declared "a private feud" by the court.
sen.cmt: "actively participated"→"served""when he became"→"after becoming""and triggered"→", triggering""and sought the"→"although he sought""denied as"→"declared"
sen.e: He served as a guard for the Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visits and suppressed rebelling Mount Hiei monks, but after becoming Mutsu no kuni no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province), he interfered in the internal conflict of the Kiyohara clan, triggering the Later Three Years' War which, although he sought official post-war consent, was declared 'a private feud' by the court.
sen.cmt: 用語集より、陸奥国守→Mutsu no kuni no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province)に統一しました。原文の「」に合わせて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: その後約10年間は閉塞状態であったが、白河天皇の意向で昇殿を許されたが、中御門右大臣・藤原宗忠はその日記『中右記』承徳2年10月23日条に「義家朝臣は天下第一武勇の士なり。
sen.e: There was a blockade condition for the later ten years, but he was allowed to visit the imperial palace by the consent from the Emperor Shirakawa, but U-daijin (the chief of an Imperial Japanese Council of State) and Nakamikado FUJIWARA no Minetada wrote in his diary, "Chuyu-ki" (dated October 23, 1099), 'Minamoto Chosin (person who served the imperial court) is the only and best bushi of the emperor.
sen.cmt: 義家朝臣は天下第一武勇の士なり。→ 'Minamoto Chosin (person who served the imperial court) is the only and best bushi of the emperor. [http://www.geocities.jp/ktmchi/rekisi/cys_51.html]
sen.e: For the next ten years he was under house arrest, but he was allowed to visit the imperial palace with Emperor Shirakawa's consent, although Udaijin (Minister of the Right) NAKIMIKADO, whose real name was FUJIWARA no Munetada, wrote in his diary, "Chuyu-ki" (dated October 23, 1099), 'Minamoto Chosin (person who served the imperial court) is the Emperor's best and bravest bushi.
sen.cmt: I'm not sure if 'house arrest' is the right term in this situation but it seems better than the original translation."Minetada"→"Munetada"I think 'Nakamikado' was another name he used, not a title"only and best"→"best and bravest"Capitalized 'e' of "emperor"
sen.e: For the next ten years he was under house arrest, but he was allowed to visit the imperial palace with Emperor Shirakawa's consent, although Udaijin (Minister of the Right) Nakamikado, also as known as FUJIWARA no Munetada, wrote in his diary, "Chuyu-ki" (dated October 23, 1099), 'Minamoto no Asomi (second highest of the eight hereditary titles) is the Emperor's best and bravest bushi.
sen.cmt: Nakamikado小文字にしました。whose real name wasをalso as known asとしました。朝臣→Asomi (second highest of the eight hereditary titles)、称号です。訂正しました。

sen.j: 昇殿をゆるさるるに、世人、甘心せざるの気あるか」と書く。
sen.e: However, there are indications that the public does not approve of his visit to the imperial palace.'
sen.cmt: 昇殿をゆるさるるに、世人、甘心せざるの気あるか→However, there are indications that the public does not approve of his visit to the imperial palace.'[http://www.geocities.jp/ktmchi/rekisi/cys_51.html]
sen.e: However, there are indications that the public does not approve of his visit to the imperial palace.'
However, there are indications that the public does not approve of his visit to the Imperial Palace.'
sen.cmt: Imperial Palace大文字にしました。

sen.j: その活動時期は摂関政治から院政に移り変わる頃であり、政治経済はもとより社会秩序においても大きな転換の時代にあたる。
sen.e: The period when he was active was when the political system was shifting from Sekkan seiji (regency government) to the In-sei (government by a retired emperor) and a giant change was observed within the political economy and stability.

He was active at a time when the political system was shifting from a regency government (Sekkan seiji) to government by a retired emperor (In-sei), resulting in huge political, economic and social changes.
sen.cmt: "The period when he was active was"→"He was active at a time"Swapped Japanese and Englsh definitions around"giant change was observed within the political economy and stability"→"resulting in huge political, economic and social changes"
sen.e: He was active at a time when the political system was shifting from a regency government (Sekkan seiji) to government by a retired emperor (In-sei), resulting in huge political, economic and social changes.

sen.j: このため歴史学者からは、義家は新興武士勢力の象徴ともみなされ、後三年の役の朝廷の扱いも「白河院の陰謀」「摂関家の陰謀」など様々な憶測がされてきた。
sen.e: As a result, historians assumed that Yoshiie represented the new rising bushi class, and the treatment of imperial court on the Later Three Years' War was considered to be the 'conspiracy of Shirakawa-in (retired Emperor Shirakawa)' or 'the conspiracy of Sekkan-ke (Sekkan families).'

As a result, historians believe that, since Yoshiie represented the new rising bushi class, his treatment by the imperial court over the Later Three Years' War was a 'conspiracy of Shirakawa-in (retired Emperor Shirakawa)' or a 'conspiracy of the Sekkan-ke (the five houses of the Fujiwara clan that usually held the regency).'

As a result, historians believe that, since Yoshiie represented the new rising bushi class, his treatment by the imperial court over the Later Three Years' War was a 'conspiracy of Shirakawain (Retired Emperor Shirakawa)' or a 'conspiracy of the Sekkan-ke (the five houses of the Fujiwara clan that usually held the regency).'
sen.cmt: スペース削除。ハイフン削除。Retired大文字にしました。

sen.j: 生前の極位は正四位下。
sen.e: His highest official rank before his death was Shoshiinoge (the Lower Fourth Court Rank).
His highest official rank before his death was Shoshiinoge (the Lower Fourth Court Rank).
His highest official rank before his death was Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 用語集より、正四位下→Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade)としました。

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Life
Life
Life

tit.e: The Date of Birth and Death

sen.j: 生没とも諸説あってはっきりしないが、68歳で死去とする史料が多く、またその没年は、史料としての信頼性が最も高い『中右記』1106年（嘉承1）7月15日条から逆算し、1039年（長暦3）の生まれとする説が有力である。
sen.e: There were various theories on the dates of his birth and death and remain uncertain, but many references pointed out that he died at the age of 68, and it is mostly likely that he was born in 1039 by calculating back from the most reliable "Chuyu-ki" (dated July 15, 1106).

There are various theories about the dates of his birth and death and they remain uncertain, but many references point out that he died at the age of 68, and by calculating back from the most reliable "Chuyu-ki" entry, dated July 15, 1106, it is mostly likely that he was born in 1039.

There are various theories about the dates of his birth and death and they remain uncertain, but many references point out that he died at the age of 68, and by calculating back from the most reliable "Chuyu-ki" entry, dated July 15, 1106, it is mostly likely that he was born in 1039.

sen.j: 源頼義の長男として、河内源氏の本拠地である河内国石川郡壷井（現大阪府羽曳野市壷井）の香炉峰の館に生まれたという説、鎌倉で生まれたとの説もあるが、いずれも伝承の域を出ない。
sen.e: There were theories that he was born as the eldest son of MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi in the Koroho-no-yakata (residence) in Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture or Kamakura, but they remain within the realm of folklores.

There are theories that he was the eldest son of MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, born in the Koroho-no-yakata (residence) in Kamakura (present day Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture), but they remain within the realm of conjecture.

There are theories that he was the eldest son of MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, born in Koroho residence in Kamakura (present day Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture), but they remain within the realm of conjecture.
sen.cmt: 香炉峰の館→Koroho residenceとしました。

sen.j: 幼名は不動丸、または源太丸。
sen.e: His childhood name is Fudomaru or Gentamaru.
His childhood name was Fudomaru or Gentamaru.
His childhood name was Fudomaru or Gentamaru.

sen.j: 七歳の春に、京都郊外の石清水八幡宮で元服したことから八幡太郎と称す。
sen.e: He went through the genpuku (Coming of Age Ceremony) at Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, outside Kyoto, during the spring of his seventh year and named himself Hachiman-taro.
He went through the genpuku (Coming of Age) Ceremony at Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, outside Kyoto, during the spring of his seventh year and took the name Hachiman-taro.
sen.cmt: Moved closing bracket"named himself"→"took the name"
sen.e: He went through the genpuku (Coming of Age) ceremony at Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine, outside Kyoto, during the spring of his seventh year and took the name Hachimantaro.
sen.cmt: ceremonny小文字にしました。ハイフン削除、スペース補足、H大文字にしました。

tit.j: 前九年の役から下野守まで
tit.e: From the Earlier Nine Years' War to Shimotsuke-no-kami (the Lord of Shimotsuke)
From the Earlier Nine Years' War to Shimotsuke-no-kami (the Lord of Shimotsuke)
From the Earlier Nine Years' War to Shimotsuke no kami (the governer of Shimotsuke Province)
tit.cmt: 用語集より、下野守→Shimotsuke no kami (the governer of Shimotsuke Province)としました。

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍、陸奥守に任ぜられた父頼義が安倍氏 (奥州)と戦った前九年の役では、1057年（天喜5）11月に数百の死者を出し大敗した黄海の戦いを経験。
sen.e: His father Yoriyoshi, who held titles of Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of North) and Matsu-no-kami (the Lord of Mutsu), experienced a great defeat at the Battle of Kiumi which produced several hundred casualties in November 1057 in the Earlier Nine Years' War against the Abe clan.

In November 1057, during the Earlier Nine Years' War against the Abe clan, his father Yoriyoshi, who held the titles Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of North) and Matsu-no-kami (the Lord of Mutsu), suffered a huge defeat at the Battle of Kiumi, resulting in several hundred casualties.
sen.cmt: Changed word order"experienced a great"→"suffered a huge defeat""which produced"→"resulting in"
sen.e: His father Yoriyoshi, who held the titles Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of North) and Mutsu no kami (the governer of Mutsu Province), suffered a great defeat at the Battle of Kiumi resulting in several hundred casualties in November 1057 during the Earlier Nine Years' War against the Abe clan.
sen.cmt: 用語集より、陸奥守→Mutsu no kami (the governer of Mutsu Province)としました。

sen.j: その後出羽国の清原氏の応援を得て父頼義はやっと安倍氏を平定する。
sen.e: His father Yoriyoshi finally suppressed the Abe clan with the assistance from the Kiyohara clan of Dewa-no-kuni (Dewa Province).
Yoriyoshi finally defeated the Abe clan with the assistance of the Kiyohara clan of Dewa-no-kuni (Dewa Province).
Yoriyoshi finally defeated the Abe clan with the assistance of the Kiyohara clan of Dewa no kuni (Dewa Province).
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足。

sen.j: しかし、『奥州後三年記』（『続群書類従』収録）には清原家衡の乳母の千任に、「なんぢが父頼義、安倍貞任、安倍宗任をうちえずして、名簿 (名札)をさヽげて故清将軍（鎮守府将軍・清原武則）をかたらひたてまつれり。
sen.e: However, it was mentioned in "Oshu-gosannen-ki" (A Chronicle of Later Three Years' War in Oshu) (recorded in "Zoku-Gunsho-Ruiju") that he was taunted by Sento, the nurse of Iehara KIYOHARA, 'Thy father Yoriyoshi could not suppress Sadato ABE and Muneto ABE so he presented myobu (full name and rank presented from the servant to the master to pledge an oath) to the late Shogun Sei (Chinjufu Shogun, KIYOHARA no Takenori) to ally with him.
sen.cmt: 名簿→myobu (full name and rank presented from the servant to the master to serve) [http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/187663/m0u/名簿/], 清将軍→Shogun Sei と判断しました。
sen.e: However, as recorded in the "Zoku-Gunsho-Ruiju," the "Oshu-gosannen-ki" (A Chronicle of The Later Three Years' War in Oshu) mentioned that Sento, the nurse of Iehara KIYOHARA, taunted Yoshiie saying 'Thy father Yoriyoshi could not defeat Sadato ABE and Muneto ABE, so he had to pledge allegience and subservience (myobu) to the late Shogun Sei (the Chinjufu Shogun, or "Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North" KIYOHARA no Takenori) in order to make an alliance.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderDeleted brackets"presented myobu (full name and rank presented from the servant to the master to pledge an oath)"→"had to pledge allegience and subservience (myobu)"Added definition of Chinjufu Shogun"to ally with him"→"in order to make an alliance"
sen.e: However, as recorded in the "Zoku-Gunsho-Ruiju," the "Oshu-gosannen-ki" (A Chronicle of The Later Three Years' War in Oshu) mentioned that Sento, the nurse of Iehara KIYOHARA, taunted Yoshiie saying 'Thy father Yoriyoshi could not defeat Sadato ABE and Muneto ABE, so he had to pledge allegiance and subservience (myobu) to the late Shogun Sei (the Chinjufu Shogun, or "Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North" KIYOHARA no Takenori) in order to make an alliance.

sen.j: ひとへにそのちからにてたまたま安倍貞任らをうちえたり。
sen.e: By gaining power from it, he was able to suppress Sadato ABE group just by chance.'
Only in this way could he defeat them.'
Only in this way could he defeat them.'

sen.j: 」といわれて激怒したことが載っているが、「名簿」（みょうぶ）を差しだし、臣下の礼をとったかどうかはともかく、それに近い平身低頭で参戦を頼みこんだことが判る。
sen.e: The book mentioned that Yoshiie became furious from hearing such comment, but even if his father presented 'myobu' to pledge an allegiance or not, it was obvious that he asked the another to join the war while being close to begging down on his knees.

The book mentioned that Yoshiie became furious upon hearing this, but whether his father pledged allegiance or not, it was obvious that he had been close to begging down on his knees in order to gain an ally in the war.

sen.e: The book mentioned that Yoshiie became furious upon hearing this, but whether his father pledged allegiance or not, it was obvious that he had been close to begging down on his knees in order to gain an ally in the war.

sen.j: 1063年（康平6）2月25日に義家はその勲功を賞され従五位下出羽国守に叙任される。
sen.e: Yoshiie was awarded for his meritorious deeds by being assigned as the Jugoi no Ge (the Lower Fifth Court Rank) of the Dewa-kokushu (Lord of Dewa) on February 25, 1063.
Yoshiie was awarded for his valor by being assigned to the Jugoi no Ge (the Lower Fifth Court Rank) of the Dewa-kokushu (Lord of Dewa) on February 25, 1063.
sen.cmt: "meritorious deeds by being assigned as"→"his valor by being assigned to"
sen.e: Yoshiie was awarded for his valor by being assigned to the Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) of Dewa no kuni no kami (Governor of Dewa Province) on February 25, 1063.
sen.cmt: 用語集より、従五位下→Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)出羽国守→Dewa no kuni no kami (Governor of Dewa Province)としました、

sen.j: しかし出羽国はその清原氏の本拠地である。
sen.e: However, Dewa-no-kuni was the headquarter of the Kiyohara clan.
However, Dewa-no-kuni was the headquarters of the Kiyohara clan.
However, Dewa no kuni was the headquarters of the Kiyohara clan.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足。

sen.j: 清原武則には前九年の役で頭を下げた経緯もあり受領としての任国経営が思うに任せなかったのか、『朝野群載』には、翌年朝廷に越中国守への転任を希望したことが記されている。
sen.e: There was a written record that KIYOHARA no Takenori expressed a wish to the imperial court to change assigned position to the Ecchu-kokushu (the Lord of Ecchu Province) on the following year, perhaps due to having a bad experience in the Earlier Nine Years' War and seemed to badly manage his assigned kuni (province).

It was recorded that, the following year, KIYOHARA no Takenori expressed a wish to the imperial court to be reassigned to the Ecchu-kokushu (the Lord of Ecchu Province), possibly due to his experiences in the Earlier Nine Years' War and his apparent mismanagement of his assigned province.
sen.cmt: "There was a written record"→"It was recorded that"Changed word order"seemed to badly manage his assigned kuni (province)"→"his apparent mismanagement of his assigned province"
sen.e: It was recorded that, the following year, KIYOHARA no Takenori expressed a wish to the Imperial Court to be reassigned to the Ecchu no kuni no kami (Governor of Ecchu Province), possibly due to his experiences in the Earlier Nine Years' War and his apparent mismanagement of his assigned province.
sen.cmt: Imperial Court大文字にしました。用語集より、越中国守→Ecchu no kuni no kami (Governor of Ecchu Province)

sen.j: ただしそれが承認されたかどうかは不明である。
sen.e: However, it is unclear if this request was granted.
However, it is unclear if this request was granted.
However, it is unclear if this request was granted.

sen.j: 尚、この年、義家は在京しており美濃において美濃源氏の祖源国房と合戦している。
sen.e: During that year, Yoshiie was in Kyoto and battled with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa, the ancestor of the Mino Genji (the Mino branch of the Minamoto clan) at Mino.
During that year, Yoshiie was in Kyoto and battled with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa, the ancestor of the Mino Genji (the Mino branch of the Minamoto clan) at Mino.
During that year, Yoshiie was in Kyoto and battled with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa, the ancestor of the Mino-Genji (Minamoto clan) at Mino.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足、説明訂正しました。

sen.j: 1070年（延久2）義家は下野国守となっており、陸奥国で印と国庫の鍵を盗んだ藤原基通 (散位)を捕らえたことが『扶養略記』8月1日条に見える。
sen.e: The "Fuso-Ryakki" entry for August 1 shows that by 1070, Yoshiie had become the Shimotsuke-kokushu (Lord of Ecchu Province) captured FUJIWARA no Motomichi (San-I (having no official title)) who stole the stamp and key to the national vault at Mutsu-no-kuni (Mutsu province).

The "Fuso-Ryakki" entry for August 1 shows that by 1070, Yoshiie had become the Shimotsuke-kokushu (Lord of Ecchu Province) and had arrested FUJIWARA no Motomichi (no official title) for stealing the stamp and key to the national vault in Mutsu-no-kuni (Mutsu province).
sen.cmt: Changed word order"Ecchu"→"Shimotsuke""captured"→"and had arrested""who stole"→"for stealing""at"→"in"
sen.e: The "Fuso-Ryakki" entry for August 1 shows that by 1070, Yoshiie had become the Shimotsuke no kami and had arrested FUJIWARA no Motomichi (no official title) for stealing the stamp and key to the national vault in Mutsu no kuni (Mutsu Province).
sen.cmt: 用語集より、下野守→Shimotsuke no kami (the governer of Shimotsuke Province)としました。前出。陸奥国→Mutsu no kuni (Mutsu Province)と訂正しました。

sen.j: 当時の陸奥国守は大和源氏の源頼俊で、即位間もない後三条天皇が源頼俊らに北陸奥の征服を命じており、北陸奥の征服自体は成功したが、この藤原基通の件の為か大和源氏源頼俊には恩賞はなく、その後の受領任官も記録には見えない。
sen.e: Mutsu-kokushu at that time was MINAMOTO no Yoritoshi of the Yamato Genji (the Yamato branch of the Minamoto clan), and the Emperor Gosanjo ordered Minamoto no Yoritoshi group to conquer North Mutsu, which succeeded, but no reward was given to MINAMOTO no Yoritoshi of the Yamato Genji due to FUJIWARA no Motomichi incidence, and was not presented in future records that he received estates or was assigned with a new post.

The Lord of Mutsu at that time was Yoshiie's father, MINAMOTO no Yoritoshi of the Yamato Genji (the Yamato branch of the Minamoto clan), and the newly enthroned Emperor Gosanjo ordered him to conquer North Mutsu but even though he succeeded, he received no reward, possibly due to the FUJIWARA no Motomichi incident, and there is no record that he received any land or new postions later..
sen.cmt: "Mutsu-kokushu"→"The Lord of Mutsu"Added "Yoshiie's father"Added "newly enthroned""Minamoto no Yoritoshi group"→"him""incidence"→"incident"Rewrote last clause
sen.e: The governer of Mutsu Province at that time was Yoshiie's father, MINAMOTO no Yoritoshi of the Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan), and the newly enthroned Emperor Gosanjo ordered him to conquer North Mutsu but even though he succeeded, he received no reward, possibly due to the FUJIWARA no Motomichi incident, and there is no record that he received any land or new postions later.
sen.cmt: The governer of Mutsu Province に表現を統一しました。Yamato-Genjiハイフン補足。括弧内説明訂正しました。余分なピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: この件に関して野口実氏は義家陰謀説も出されている。
sen.e: Minoru NOGUCHI pointed out the Yoshiie Conspiracy Theory about this incidence.
Minoru NOGUCHI has put forward the Yoshiie Conspiracy Theory about this incident.
Minoru NOGUCHI has put forward the Yoshiie Conspiracy Theory about this incident.

tit.e: Souga (Claws and Fangs) of Shirakawa-tei (the Emperor Shirakawa)
Souga (Claws and Fangs) of Emperor Shirakawa
Souga (Claws and Fangs) of Emperor Shirakawa

sen.j: 1079年（承暦3）8月 美濃国で源国房と闘乱を起こした右兵衛尉源重宗（清和源氏満正流４代）を官命により追討。
sen.e: He subjugated U-hyoenokami, MINAMOTO no Shigemune (the fourth generation of the Mansei line of the Seiwa branch of the Minamoto clan) who caused the feud with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa in Mino-no-kuni, under orders from the imperial court.

In August 1079, he was ordered by the Imperial Court to hunt down and kill U-hyoenokami, MINAMOTO no Shigemune (the fourth generation of the Mansei line of the Seiwa branch of the Minamoto clan) for causing the feud with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa in Mino-no-kuni.
sen.cmt: Not sure of English for "U-hyoenokami"Added dateChanged word order"subjugated"→"hunt down and kill""under orders from the imperial court"→"he was ordered by the imperial court"
sen.e: In August 1079, he was ordered by the Imperial Court to hunt down and kill Uhyoe no jo (officer of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards), MINAMOTO no Shigemune (the fourth generation of the Mansei line of the Seiwa branch of the Minamoto clan) for causing the feud with MINAMOTO no Kunifusa in Mino Province.
sen.cmt: 用語集より、右兵衛尉→Uhyoe no jo (officer of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards)。Mino-no-kuniをMino Provinceに訂正しました。

sen.j: 1081年（永保1）9月14日に検非違使とともに園城寺の悪僧を追補 （『扶桑略記』）。
sen.e: He chased and captured the akuso (warrior monk) with the Kebiishi (body of police commissioners in the Heian period) on September 14, 1081 ("Fuso Ryakki").
According to the "Fuso-Ryakki," on September 14, 1081, with the Kebiishi (Imperial police), he chased and captured a warrior monk from Onjo-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderAdded "Onjou-ji Temple"Changed definition of "Kebiishi"
sen.e: According to the "Fuso-Ryakki," on September 14, 1081, with the kebiishi (police and judicial chief), he chased and captured a warrior monk from Onjo-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 用語集より、検非違使→kebiishi (a police and judicial chief)に訂正しました。

sen.j: その年の10月14日には白河天皇の石清水八幡宮行幸に際し、その園城寺の悪僧（僧兵）の襲撃を防ぐために、弟・源義綱と二人でそれぞれの郎党を率いてを護衛したが、このとき本官（官職）が無かったため関白・藤原師実の前駆の名目で護衛を行った。
sen.e: He accompanied Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visit to Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, and tried to prevent attacks by akuso of Onjo-ji Temple by guarding with his younger brother, MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna by leading their roto (servants to bushi), but since they did not have Honkan (official government post), they guarded the emperor with an excuse of being the front runner for Kanpaku (a chancellor) FUJIWARA no Morozane.

On October 14 the same year, he accompanied Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visit to Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, and in order to prevent attacks by the warrior monks of Onjo-ji Temple, formed an escort with his younger brother, MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna, and their retainers but, since they held no official postion, they guarded the Emperor using the excuse of being outriders for Kanpaku (chancellor) FUJIWARA no Morozane.
sen.cmt: Added "On October 14 the same year""by leading their roto (servants to bushi)"→"and their retainers""they did not have Honkan (official government post)"→"they held no official postion""the front runner"→"outriders"Added "the"
sen.e: On October 14 the same year, he accompanied Emperor Shirakawa during his imperial visit to Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine, and in order to prevent attacks by the warrior monks of Onjo-ji Temple, formed an escort with his younger brother, MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna, and their retainers but, since they held no official position, they guarded the Emperor using the excuse of being outriders for Kanpaku (chancellor) FUJIWARA no Morozane.
sen.cmt: Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu をIwashimizu Hachiman-guに訂正、表記統一しました。Shrinenopositionスペル訂正しました。

sen.j: さらに帰りが夜となったので義家は束帯（朝廷での正式な装束）から非常時に戦いやすい布衣（ほい：常服）に着替え、弓箭（きゅうせん）を帯して白河天皇の乗輿の側らで警護にあたり、藤原為房の『為房卿記』には、「布衣の武士、鳳輦（ほうれん）に扈従（こしゅう）す。
sen.e: In addition, since the returning trip was at night, Yoshiie changed from soukutai (traditional formal court dress) to Hoi (traditional everyday clothes), which was easy to fight in the case of emergency, and armed themselves with kyusen (bow and arrow) to guard on the sides of vehicle of Emperor Shirakawa, and FUJIWARA no Tamefusa commented in "Tamefusa-kyo-ki" (A Diary of FUJIWARA no Tamefusa), 'bushi in hoi, koshu (attend) to Horen (an imperial carriage).

In addition, since the return trip was at night, Yoshiie changed from soukutai (traditional formal court dress) to hoi (everyday clothes), which were easier to fight in case of emergency and, armed with bows and arrows, formed an escort on either side of the Emperor's palanquin, leading FUJIWARA no Tamefusa to comment in "Tamefusa-kyo-ki" (A Diary of FUJIWARA no Tamefusa), 'Plain-clothed warriors attending the imperial carriage.
sen.cmt: "returning"→"return"Deleted "traditional""was easy"→"were easier"Deleted "the"Deleted "themselves"Deleted "kyusen "and brackets"to guard on the sides of vehicle of Emperor Shirakawa"→"formed an escort on either side of the Emperor's palanquin"Rewrote quote
sen.e: In addition, since the return trip was at night, Yoshiie changed from soukutai (traditional formal court dress) to hoi (everyday clothes), which were easier to fight in case of emergency and, armed with bows and arrows, formed an escort on either side of the Emperor's palanquin, leading FUJIWARA no Tamefusa to comment in "Tamefusa-kyo-ki" (A Diary of FUJIWARA no Tamefusa), 'Plain-clothed warriors attending the imperial carriage.

sen.j: 未だかつて聞かざる事也」と書かれている。
sen.e: It is something unheard of even now.'
It has never been heard of.'
sen.cmt: "is something unheard of even now"→"has never been heard of"
sen.e: It has never been heard of.'

sen.j: 同年12月 4日の白河天皇の春日社行幸に際しては義家は甲冑をつけ、弓箭を帯した100名の兵を率いて白河天皇を警護する。
sen.e: On December 4 of the same year, Yoshiie guarded Emperor Shirakawa while wearing Japanese armor and helmet and lead 100 army men with kyusen.
On December 4 of the same year, Yoshiie led 100 men wearing armor and helmets and armed with bows and arrows as a bodyguard during Emperor Shirakawa's visit to Kasuga Shrine.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderAdded "Kasuga Shrina" as in original
sen.e: On December 4 of the same year, Yoshiie led 100 men wearing armor and helmets and armed with bows and arrows as a bodyguard during Emperor Shirakawa's visit to Kasuga-sha Shrine.

sen.j: この段階では公卿達の日記『水左記』などにも「近日の例」と書かれるようになり、官職によらず天皇を警護することが普通のことと思われはじめる。
sen.e: By this time, it was considered to be a norm to guard the emperor disregarding governmental position as mentioned in the diary of kugyo (aristocrats), "Suisa-ki" as an 'example of nowadays.'

By this time, it was beginning to be considered the norm to guard the emperor without regard to governmental position, as can be seen in entries such as 'an example of nowadays' in the "Suisa-ki" diary of the kugyo (aristocrats).
sen.cmt: Added "beginning to be""disregarding"→"without regard to"Changed word order.
sen.e: By this time, it was beginning to be considered the norm to guard the emperor without regard to governmental position, as can be seen in entries such as 'an example of nowadays' in the "Suisa-ki" diary of the kugyo (aristocrats).

sen.j: のちの「北面の武士」の下地にもなった出来事である。
sen.e: This event became the ground for the formation of the later 'Hokumen no Bushi (royal guards).'
This event became the basis for the formation of the 'Hokumen no Bushi (royal guards).'
This event became the basis for the formation of the 'Hokumen no bushi' (the Imperial Palace Guards for the north side).
sen.cmt: 用語集より、「北面の武士」→'Hokumen no bushi' (the Imperial Palace Guards for the north side)と訂正しました。

sen.j: この頃から義家・義綱兄弟は白河帝に近侍している。
sen.e: Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna brothers served their master, Shirakawa-tei, at a close range from this time.
From this time, the brothers, Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna, closely attended the Emperor.
sen.cmt: Changed word order."served their master, Shirakawa-tei, at a close range"→"closely attended the Emperor"
sen.e: From this time, the brothers, Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna, closely attended the Emperor.

sen.j: 1083年（永保3）に陸奥国守となり、出羽清原氏の内紛に介入して後三年の役がはじまる。
sen.e: In 1083, Yoshiie became the Mutsu-kokushu and involved with the internal conflict of Kiyohara clan in Dewa to trigger the Later Three Years' War.
In 1083, Yoshiie became the Mutsu-kokushu and got involved in the Kiyohara clan's internal conflict in Dewa, triggering the Later Three Years' War.
In 1083, Yoshiie became the Mutsu no kuni no kami and got involved in the Kiyohara clan's internal conflict in Dewa, triggering the Later Three Years' War.
sen.cmt: Mutsu no kuni no kamiと訂正しました。

sen.j: ただしこの合戦は朝廷の追討官符による公戦ではない。
sen.e: However, this battle was not the official war declared by the imperial court to subjugate the enemy.
However, this battle was not the official one of subjugation declared by the Imperial Court.
However, this battle was not the official one of subjugation declared by the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 朝廷では1087年（寛治1）7月9日に「奥州合戦停止」の官使の派遣を決定した事実も有る事から、『後二条師通記』にはこの戦争は「義家合戦」と私戦を臭わせる書き方がされている。
sen.e: The imperial court declared the 'Termination of Oshu Kassen' (the Battle of Oshu) on July 9, 1087, and "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" (A Diary of Gonijo Moromichi) wrote this war as more of a private war, referring to it as 'Yoshiie Battle,'

The Imperial Court dispatched the 'Termination of the Battle of Oshu' declaration on July 9, 1087, and is described as a private war in "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" (A Diary of Gonijo Moromichi), which also refers to it as 'Yoshiie's Battle.'

The Imperial Court dispatched the 'Termination of the Battle of Oshu' declaration on July 9, 1087, and is described as a private war in "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" (A Diary of Gonijo Moromichi), which also refers to it as 'Yoshiie's Battle.'

sen.j: 後三年の役において動員した兵は、石井進 (歴史学者)氏のにそって分類すれば、国守軍の「館の者共」、つまり受領国守の私的郎党として動員した近畿から美濃国、そして相模国の武者（大半は側近、または京でのコネクションを思わせる辺境軍事貴族）と、清原氏勢力外の陸奥南部の「国の兵共」。
sen.e: Categorizing in the way of Susumu ISHII (historian), the mobilized soldiers at the Later Three Years' War were Kokushu army (Provincial army), 'Yakata no mono tomo' (people of the residential hall) (private army of the provinces granted by the emperor from Mino-no-kuni from Kinki area), Sagami-no-kuni (Segami Province) bushi (most of them were borderline military aristocrats who may have had tight connections to Kyoto), and 'Kuni-no-heidomo' (Soldiers of the Province) of southern Mutsu outside the control of the Kiyohara clan.

According to historian Susumu ISHII, the armies at the Later Three Years' War were the Kokushu (Daimyo's) Army, known as the 'Yakata no mono tomo' (people of the manor), a private army of bushi (most of whom were borderline military aristocrats from who may have had close connections to Kyoto) from Mino-no-kuni and Sagami-no-kuni Provinces, mobilized as private retainers of the daimyo, and the 'Kuni-no-heidomo' (Soldiers of the Province) of southern Mutsu, which was outside the Kiyohara clan's control.
sen.cmt: Rewrote sentence, especially definition of 国守軍 but not sure if I've got it perfectly.
sen.e: According to historian Susumu ISHII, the armies at the Later Three Years' War were the Kokushu (Daimyo's) Army, known as the 'Yakata no monodomo' (people of the manor), a private army of bushi (most of whom were borderline military aristocrats from who may have had close connections to Kyoto) from Mino and Sagami Provinces, mobilized as private retainers of the daimyo, and the 'Kuni-no-heidomo' (Soldiers of the Province) of southern Mutsu, which was outside the Kiyohara clan's control.
sen.cmt: 館の者共→Yakata no monodomoに訂正しました。スペース削除しました。from Mino and Sagami Provincesに訂正しました。Kuni no heidomo、ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 「地方豪族軍」として陸奥国奥六郡の南三郡を中心とした清原清衡の軍と、そもそもの発端の当事者であり、後三年の役では後半に加勢したらしい出羽国の吉彦秀武の軍からなると思われる。
sen.e: There were also KIYOHARA no Kiyohira's 'Powerful Local Clan Army' who based themselves in three southern districts of Okuroku-gun (Okuroku district), Segami-no-kuni and the army of KIMIKO no Hidetake from Dewa-no-kuni, who directly caused and participated in the later half of the Later Three Years' War.

There were also KIYOHARA no Kiyohira's 'Powerful Local Clan Army' based in the three southern districts of Okuroku-gun, Mutsu-no-kuni and the army of KIMIKO no Hidetake from Dewa-no-kuni, who had been involved in the incident from the beginning and participated in the latter half of the Later Three Years' War.

There were also KIYOHARA no Kiyohira's 'Powerful Local Clan Army' based in the three southern districts of Okuroku-gun, Mutsu Province and the army of KIMIKO no Hidetake from Dewa Province, who had been involved in the incident from the beginning and participated in the latter half of the Later Three Years' War.
sen.cmt: Mutsu Province、Dewa Provinceと訂正しました。

sen.j: 最終局面での主要な作戦が吉彦秀武から出ていること、及び前九年の役の例を勘案すれば、最大兵力は、戦場となった地元出羽国の吉彦秀武の軍、次ぎに当事者清原清衡の軍であり、国守軍は陸奥南部の「国の兵共」を加えたとしても、それほど多かったとは思えない。
sen.e: By considering the fact that the main battle operation near the end of the war came from KIMIKO no Hidetake, and seeing Earlier Nine Years' War events, the biggest military forces consisted of KIMIKO no Hidetake army at the local Dewa-no-kuni, where the battle field took place, Kiyohara no Kiyohira army, and Kokushu army, on the other hand, could not have been big even if 'Kuni-no-heidomo' of the southern Mutsu was added.

Considering the fact that the main action near the end of the war came from KIMIKO no Hidetake, and taking into consideration examples from the Earlier Nine Years' War, the biggest military force was KIMIKO no Hidetake's army from Dewa-no-kuni, where the battle took place, followed by Kiyohara no Kiyohira's army, while the Kokushu army, even if the 'Kuni-no-heidomo' from southern Mutsu was added, could not have been so big.

Considering the fact that the main action near the end of the war came from KIMIKO no Hidetake, and taking into consideration examples from the Earlier Nine Years' War, the biggest military force was KIMIKO no Hidetake's army from Dewa Province, where the battle took place, followed by KIYOHARA no Kiyohira's army, while the government army, even if the 'Kuni no heidomo' from southern Mutsu was added, could not have been so big.
sen.cmt: Dewa Provinceと訂正しました。KIYOHARA大文字にしました。Kokushuをgovernmentとしました。Kuni no heidomo、ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 1087（寛治1）11月に義家は出羽国金沢柵にて清原武衡、清原家衡を破り、12月、それを報告する「国解」の中で「わたくしの力をもって、たまたまうちたいらぐる事をえたり。
sen.e: In November 1087, Yoshiie suppressed KIYOHARA no Takehira and KIYOHARA no Iehara at Kanazawa-saku of Dewa-no-kuni, and it was reported in 'Kokuge' (an official report to the government), 'I defeated them with my own power by chance.

In November 1087, Yoshiie defeated KIYOHARA no Takehira and KIYOHARA no Iehara at Kanazawa fortress in Dewa-no-kuni, and he reported in 'Kokuge' (an official report to the government), 'Using my own power, I was lucky enough to defeat them.

In November 1087, Yoshiie defeated KIYOHARA no Takehira and KIYOHARA no Iehara at Kanazawa fortress in Dewa Province, and he reported in 'Kokuge' (an official report to the government), 'Using my own power, I was lucky enough to defeat them.

sen.j: 早く追討の官符を給わりて」と後付けの追討官符を要請するが、朝廷はこれを下さず、「私戦」としたため恩賞はなく、かつ翌年1088年（寛治2）正月には陸奥守を罷免される。
sen.e: Please give me kanpu (official written command from the imperial court) fast,' and sought the official post-war kanpu for subjugating the enemy but was rejected by the imperial court which considered it as a 'private war,' and no reward was made and took away Mutsu-no-kami in the following January 1088.

Please give me kanpu (official written command from the imperial court) fast,' and sought official post-war consent for defeating the enemy but was rejected by the Court which, because it considered it a 'private war,' made no reward and in January the following year, he was removed as Mutsu-no-kami.

Please give me kanpu (official written command from the Imperial Court) fast,' and sought official post-war consent for defeating the enemy but was rejected by the Court which, because it considered it a 'private war,' made no reward and in January the following year, he was removed as the governer of Mutsu Province.
sen.cmt: Imperial Court大文字にしました。The governer of Mutsu Province に表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 何よりも陸奥国の兵（つわもの）を動員しての戦闘であり、義家自身が国解の中で「政事をとどめてひとえにつわもの（兵）をととの」、と述べているように、その間の陸奥国に定められた官物の貢納は滞ったと思われ、その後何年もの間催促されていることが、当時の記録に残る（『中右記』1096年（永長1）12月15日条、1097年（永長2） 2月25日条）。
sen.e: Yoshiie, who lead the tsuwamono (soldiers) of Mutsu-no-kuni to the battle, reported in Kokuge himself, 'stopped the politics and organize the tsuwamono,' and refrained from the tax paid to the Mutsu-no-kuni, and was repeatedly pressed by the imperial court for several years hence as recorded in ("Chuyu-ki," dated December 15, 1096 and February 25, 1097).
sen.cmt: 政事をとどめてひとえにつわもの（兵）をととの→stopped the politics and organize the tsuwamono[定訳不明]
sen.e: Yoshiie, who had led the Mutsu soldiers into battle, reported in the Kokuge, 'stop the politics and organize the soldiers,' and refrained from paying Mutsu-no-kuni's tax to the Court, which repeatedly pressed him for several years ("Chuyu-ki," dated December 15, 1096 and February 25, 1097).

Yoshiie, who had led the Mutsu soldiers into battle, reported in the Kokuge, 'stop the politics and organize the soldiers,' and refrained from paying Mutsu Province's tax to the Court, which repeatedly pressed him for several years ("Chuyu-ki," dated December 15, 1096 and February 25, 1097).

sen.j: 当時の法制度からは、定められた官物を収めて、受領功過定に合格しなければ、新たな官職に就くことができず、義家は官位もそのままに据え置かれた。
sen.e: The law at that time required the submission of a designated amount of tax to pass the Zuryo-kokka-sadame (criteria to determine if one is eligible for employment) to be assigned to the official government post, and Yoshiie's rank remained unchanged.

The law at that time required the submission of a designated amount of tax to pass the Zuryo-koka-sadame (criteria to determine if one is eligible for employment) to be assigned to an official government post, and Yoshiie's rank remained unchanged.

The law at that time required the submission of a designated amount of tax to pass the Zuryo-koka-sadame (criteria to determine if one is eligible for employment) to be assigned to an official government post, and Yoshiie's rank remained unchanged.

sen.j: 1091年（寛治5）6月 義家の郎党藤原実清と源義綱の郎党藤原則清が、河内国の所領の領有権を争い、義家・義綱兵を構える事件がおき、京を震撼させた。
sen.e: In June 1091, FUJIWARA no Sanekiyo of Yoshiie roto and FUJIWARA no Norikiyo of Minamoto Yoshitsuna roto fought over the right of the estate in Kawachi-no-kuni and shook Kyoto by mobilizing Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna armies.

In June 1091, Kyoto was shocked when Yoshiie's retainer, FUJIWARA no Sanekiyo and Minamoto Yoshitsuna's retainer, FUJIWARA no Norikiyo fought over the rights to the estate in Kawachi-no-kuni and shook Kyoto by mobilizing Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna armies.
sen.cmt: Changed word order"of Yoshiie roto"→"Yoshiie's retainer""of Minamoto Yoshitsuna roto"→"Minamoto Yoshitsuna's retainer"
sen.e: In June 1091, Kyoto was shocked when Yoshiie's retainer, FUJIWARA no Sanekiyo and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsuna's retainer, FUJIWARA no Norikiyo fought over the rights to the estate in Kawachi Province and shook Kyoto by mobilizing Yoshiie and Yoshitsuna armies.
sen.cmt: MINAMOTO no、と訂正しました。Kawachi Provinceと訂正しました。

sen.j: 弟義綱はその年1091年（寛治5）の正月に、藤原師実が節会に参内する際の行列の前駆を努めた他、翌1092年（寛治6）2月には藤原忠実が春日祭使となって奈良に赴く際の警衛、1093年（寛治7）12月には、源俊房の慶賀の参内の際に前駆を努めるなどが公卿の日記に見えるが、義家の方は1104年まで、そうした活動は記録にない。
sen.e: It was written in the kugyo diary that younger brother Yoshitsuna acted as the front runner for the procession of FUJIWARA no Morozane during the sandai (a visit to the Imperial Palace) to participate at the party in January 1091 of that year, guarded FUJIWARA no Tadazane going to Nara as the Kasugasai-shi (Kasugasai (festival in Nara Prefecture) ambassador) in February 1092, led the procession of MINAMOTO no Toshifusa during his imperial visit in December 1093, but no such activities were recorded for Yoshiie until 1104.
sen.cmt: 春日祭使→Kasugasai-shi (Kasugasai (festival in Nara Prefecture) ambassaderと判断しました。 [http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/春日祭/]
sen.e: It was written in the kugyo diary that Yoshitsuna was the outrider for FUJIWARA no Morozane's procession visit to the Imperial Palace to participate at a banquet in January 1091; in February 1092 he guarded FUJIWARA no Tadazane on the way to Nara as the Kasugasai-shi (Kasugasai festival ambassador) and led the procession of MINAMOTO no Toshifusa during his imperial visit in December 1093, but no such activities were recorded for Yoshiie until 1104.

It was written in the kugyo diary that Yoshitsuna was the outrider for FUJIWARA no Morozane's procession visit to the Imperial Palace to participate at a banquet in January 1091; in February 1092 he guarded FUJIWARA no Tadazane on the way to Nara as the Kasugasai-shi (Kasugasai festival ambassador) and led the procession of MINAMOTO no Toshifusa during his imperial visit in December 1093, but no such activities were recorded for Yoshiie until 1104.

sen.j: 1093年（寛治7）10月の除目で、義綱は陸奥守にに就任。
sen.e: Yoshitsuna was inaugurated to Mutsu-no-kami in the Jimoku (biannual inauguration ceremony of the government officials) in October 1093.
Yoshitsuna was made Mutsu-no-kami at the Jimoku biannual inauguration ceremony of the government officials in October 1093.
Yoshitsuna was made Mutsu no kami at the Jimoku biannual inauguration ceremony of the government officials in October 1093.
sen.cmt: 前出にならって、Mutsu no kamiとしました。

sen.j: 翌年の1094年（寛治8）には出羽国守を襲撃した在地の開拓領主・平師妙（もろたえ）を郎党に追捕させ、従四位上に叙されて官位は兄義家と並び、翌年の1095年（嘉保2）正月の除目で、事実上陸奥よりも格の高い美濃国守に就任する。
sen.e: He made his roto to chase and captured the TAIRA no Morotae (cultivated the wild land) who attacked the Dewa-kokushi, and was at the same governmental rank level with his older brother when awarded with Ju-shii-jo (Upper Fourth Court Rank), and was inaugurated to Mino-Kokushu (higher quality than Mutsu) in Jimoku of the following January 1095.

In 1094, his retainers chased and captured TAIRA no Morotae, who had attacked the Dewa-kokushi, and he became the same governmental rank as his older brother when he was awarded the Ju-shii-jo (Upper Fourth Court Rank), and at the Jimokuin in January of the following year, he was made Lord of Mino, a province of higher status than Mutsu.

In 1094, his retainers chased and captured TAIRA no Morotae, who had attacked the governer of Dewa Province, and he became the same governmental rank as his older brother when he was awarded the Jushiijo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade), and at the Jimoku in January of the following year, he was made the governer of Mino, a province of higher status than Mutsu.
sen.cmt: The governer of Dewa Province に表現を統一しました。用語集より、従四位上→Jushiijo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)と訂正しました。Jimokuに訂正しました。The governer ofに訂正しました。

sen.j: その美濃における延暦寺領荘園との争いで僧侶が死亡したことから、比叡山側は義綱の配流を要求して強訴に及ぶが、関白藤原師通は大和源氏の源頼治と義綱に命じてそれを実力で撃退する。
sen.e: Since monks died in the battle with the Enryaku-ji Temple which owned the shoen in Mino, the side of Mount Hiei demanded the exile of Yoshitsuna to the top officials, but Kanpaku FUJIWARA no Moromichi ordered MINAMOTO no Yoriharu and Yoshitsuna to drive them away with force.

Following the deaths of some monks in the battle with the Enryaku-ji Temple over its territory in Mino, the side of Mount Hiei petitioned for Yoshitsuna's exile, but Kanpaku FUJIWARA no Moromichi ordered MINAMOTO no Yoriharu and Yoshitsuna to deal with them with force.

sen.j: 戦後初期の義家観
sen.e: The view of Yoshiie in early post-World War II period
The view of Yoshiie in the early post-World War II period
The view of Yoshiie in the early post-World War II period

sen.j: 戦後初期の歴史学者の中での通説となったものは、石母田正の『中世的世界の形成』をベースに、古代支配階級である貴族や宗教勢力に対して、新たに発生した在地領主層（封建的農奴主階級）が武装したものが「武士」であり、その新興勢力（武士階級）が、古代支配階級である貴族や宗教勢力を排除し、鎌倉幕府という武士階級を中心とした中世世界をもたらしたという歴史観であった。
sen.e: The accepted theory and views among historians in early post-World War II period was based on "Chuseiteki sekai no keise" (The formation of the medieval world) by Tadashi ISHIMODA, which stated that "bushi" was the rising armed land lord class (the head of feudal peasant class) people who eliminated the ruling class consisting of old aristocrats and religious forces, and this new power (bushi class) founded the Kamakura bakufu controlled by the bushi class in medieval era.

The accepted theory and views among historians in early post-World War II period were based on "Chuseiteki sekai no keise" (The formation of the medieval world) by Tadashi ISHIMODA, which stated that "bushi" were the rising armed land lord class (the head of feudal peasant class), who eliminated the ruling class consisting of old aristocrats and religious forces, and this new power (bushi class) founded and controlled the Kamakura bakufu controlled in medieval era.

sen.j: 当時の学説では「武士」はその在地領主をベースとしたものであり、平将門や藤原秀郷などは学会用語としては「武士」ではなく、その前段階の「兵」（つわもの）といわれていた。
sen.e: The academic theory at that time stated that 'bushi' based themselves in their estates and did not consider TAIRA no Masakado and FUJIWARA no Hidesato as 'bushi' but 'Tsuwamono (soldier)' according to the academic vocabulary.

sen.j: そうした「重層的な階級制」は、ちょうど義家の頃に見られるようになり、その背景には、地方経済社会での大きな変動、在地での有力者は田堵・負名（公田請作経営者）から在地領主（所領経営者）へと変化があったと考えられている。
sen.e: Such 'multiple layered class system' began to appear at the time of Yoshiie, and is believed that there was a huge economic shift of the district societies, and residential land's power holder changed from Tato and Fumyo (farm managers who lease public fields from provincial lords and produced agricultural products) to the residential land lords (estate managers).

This 'multilayered class system' began to appear during Yoshiie's time, and is believed that there was a huge economic shift in local society, and power in residential land shifted from the 'Tato' and 'Fumyo' (farm managers who leased public fields from provincial lords and produced agricultural products) to the residential land lords (estate managers).

sen.j: そうした歴史の大きな流れの中で、新興勢力・武士階級と古代支配階級の最初の衝突（抑圧）を源義家の中に見ようとする傾向が大勢を占めていた。
sen.e: Many had the tendency to try to study Minamoto no Yoshiie as the first clash (suppression) between the new rising bushi and old aristocratic ruling classes in midst of such huge historical transformation.

Many people were inclined to see in Minamoto no Yoshiie the first clash (oppression) between the new rising warrior class and old aristocratic ruling classes in the context of such huge historical transformation.

sen.j: その最初の衝突（抑圧）の具体例としてあげられたのが、後三年の役の勝利にも関わらず恩賞が与えられず、冷遇されたこと、そして義家に対する荘園寄進が禁じられたことなどである。
sen.e: The first example of such clash (suppression) was the fact that Yoshiie did not receive rewards despite his victory in the Later Three Years' War and was treated coldly in addition to being banned from receiving new estates.

sen.e: In addition, Yoshiie's grandson, Minamoto no Tameyoshi, was intentionally appointed during the internal conflict of Kawachi Genji clan after the death of Yoshiie, and this further disturbed the unity within the Kawachi Genji clan.

sen.j: 白河天皇や摂関家など、当時の支配者が義家を危険視したという竹内理三、安田元久の論は、当時の国土のほとんどが荘園となっていたという認識を前提としている。
sen.e: Rulers at that time, including Emperor Shirakawa and Sekkan-ke, viewed Yoshiie as the dangerous individual based on the fact that most of the country was occupied by shoen as according to the arguments made by Rizo TAKEUCHI and Motohisa YASUDA.

sen.j: そうした状況のなかで、義家はその荘園の最上位の所有者層に割り込み、白河法皇や摂関家など、王家・上級貴族の経済基盤を脅かしたというものである。
sen.e: In the middle of such situation, Yoshiie managed to squeeze himself into the highest rank of shoen's land owners and threatened the financial platform of royal families and high class aristocrats.

sen.e: For an example, Rizo TAKEUCHI explained in "Bushi no Tojo"(1965), 'aristocrats including the retired emperor could not stand those who became shoen land lords similar to aristocrats by receiving farms from peasants of many districts.'

sen.j: その後の荘園史の進展
sen.e: The Later Development of the Historical Study of Shoen
Later Developments in the Historical Study of Shoen
Later Developments in the Historical Study of Shoen

sen.j: しかしこの論は、1970年代以降の荘園史研究の進展から、3つの点で見直しが必要とされている。
sen.e: However, this theory required to be revised in three ways from the post-1970's development of the historical study of shoen.
However, from the 1970's, developments in the study of shoen history led to this theory being revised in three ways.

sen.j: そのひとつは、網野善彦の1969年「若狭国における荘園制の形成」や石井進 (歴史学者)の1970年「院政時代」、1978年の「相武の武士団」（『鎌倉武士の実像』に収録）における「太田文」の詳細な研究から、荘園がもっとも盛んに立荘された時期は、12世紀中葉以降の鳥羽天皇・後白河天皇院政期であり、更にその大規模荘園の乱立が完了した13世紀においてさえも、荘園領と国衙領は地方により相違はあるものの、平均すれば6対4とほぼ半々であることが明らかになった。
sen.e: One is the fact that manor was mostly founded after mid-12th century during Emperors Toba and Gotoba's In-sei period and the ratio of shoen and national land remained at the average of six to four ratio or half-and-half at the completion of a large scale mushrooming of manor in 13th century as indicated by the detail study written in "Wakasa no kuni ni okeru shoensei no keisei" (The formation of manor system in Wakasa Province) (1969) proposed by Yoshihiko AMINO, "Insei jidai" (The Period of the Government by a Retired Emperor) (1970) by Susumu ISHII, "Oota Fumi" (The letters of Oota) in "Sobu no bushidan" (The bushi groups in Sobu region) (written in "Kamakura bushi no jitsuzo" (The Real Face of Kamakura Warriors).

Firstly, following detailed research that appeared in Yoshihiko AMINO's "Wakasa no kuni ni okeru shoensei no keisei" (The formation of the manor system in Wakasa Province) (1969), Susumu ISHII's "Insei jidai" (The Age of Cloistered Emperors) (1970) and "Oota Fumi" (The letters of Oota) in "Sobu no bushidan" (Bushi groups of the Sobu region), which appears in "Kamakura bushi no jitsuzo" (The Real Face of Kamakura Warriors) (1978), it became clear that most manors were established after the mid-12th century, during the reigns of the Cloistered Emperors Toba and Gotoba, and that by the time this large-scale expansion stopped in the 13th century, the ratio of shoen to national land was on average of six to four, or about even.

Firstly, following detailed research that appeared in Yoshihiko AMINO's "Wakasa no kuni ni okeru shoensei no keisei" (The formation of the manor system in Wakasa Province) (1969), Susumu ISHII's "Insei jidai" (The Age of Cloistered Emperors) (1970) and "Oota Fumi" (The letters of Oota) in "Sobu no bushidan" (Bushi groups of the Sobu region), which appears in "Kamakura bushi no jitsuzo" (The Real Face of Kamakura Warriors) (1978), it became clear that most manors were established after the mid-12th century, during the reigns of the Cloistered Emperors Toba and Gotoba, and that by the time this large-scale expansion stopped in the 13th century, the ratio of shoen to national land was on average of six to four, or about even.

sen.j: 石井進 (歴史学者)は1986年4月の「中世の村を歩く－寺院と荘園」（現在『中世の村を歩く』収録）において「摂関時代の成立とともに全国土が荘園となったという従来の説には、とても従えないのである。」と書かれている。
sen.e: Susumu ISHII (historian) wrote in "Chusei no mura o aruku - Jiin no shoen" (A walk to medieval villages- Temples and Shrines) (Currently included within "Chusei no mura o aruku"), 'I cannot believe the theory that the entire country became shoen at the same time as the establishment of Sekkan period."

The historian Susumu ISHII wrote in "Chusei no mura o aruku - Jiin no shoen" (A walk in medieval villages- Temples and Manors) (Currently the "Chusei no mura o aruku" compilation), 'I cannot believe the theory that the entire country became shoen at the same time as the establishment of the Sekkan (regency) period."

In April 1986, the historian Susumu ISHII wrote in "Chusei no mura o aruku - Jiin no shoen" (A walk in medieval villages - Temples and Manors) (Currently the "Chusei no mura o aruku" compilation), 'I cannot believe the theory that the entire country became shoen at the same time as the establishment of the Sekkan (regency) period."

sen.e: The second part is the fact that "Kizoku to Onaji Shoen-ryoke ka" (The formation of Shoen-ryoke (A lord who is donated with "Shoen" estates) same as the aristocrats) by Susumu ISHII and "Jokyu Kizoku-tachi to onajiyouni Shoen-ryoshu (Shoen-ryoke)" (Shoen-ryoshu same as high aristocrats) by Motohisa YASUDA considered Yoshiie as the highest class.

sen.j: 荘園支配の階層には荘園領主である「本所や領家」、その代官である「預所」、現地での実質支配者で、多くの場合寄進者である「庄司（下司）」の3段階があるが、その最上位が権門といわれる「上皇をふくめての貴族層」や、大寺院・神社が位置する。
sen.e: The shoen ruling class had the leader, "honjo (a head of shoen lords) and ryoke," and its substitute, "Azukaridokoro" (a deputy of shoen lord) as the actual local ruler, and in many cases, there were three classes of donating "Shoshi or Geshi (a local keeper)" in many cases, but the top most rank was the "Kenmon" which included "aristocrats including the retired emperor" and those of temples and shrines.

The shoen ranks included "honjo (head of shoen lords) and ryoke," their deputy, "azukaridokoro," and three classes of "Shoshi or Geshi," the actual local ruler and in many cases, donor, but the top most rank was the "Kenmon" which included "aristocrats including the retired emperor" and those of temples and shrines.

sen.j: 1960年代には、義家がその最上位に、権門を押しのけて、あるいは新たな権門として割り込もうとしたかのとうに捉えられていたが、これはたかだか四位の諸大夫・受領層である義家には考えにくい。

sen.j: 福田豊彦は、1974年の「王朝国家をめぐって」（『東国の兵乱ともののふたち』に収録）と言う論文で、「荘園寄進の対象（本家領家）ではなくて、寄進に当たっての媒介の役割を果たした貴族層（預所など）との接点で考える必要がありそうに思います。」と述べている。
sen.e: In the paper called "Ochokokka o megutte" (About the Monachic State) (collected in "Togoku no heiran to mononofutachi" (Wars in the Eastern Japan and Warriors)) written by Toyohiko FUKUDA in 1974 stated, 'I believe there is a need to think not from the perspective of the honke (the highest shoen class) or ryoke (who was given shoen by the imperial court) but aristocrats (such as Azukaridokoro) who acted as the mediators of donation of estates.'

sen.j: 次ぎに、「義家に対して随兵の入京禁止令」「義家への土地の寄進禁止」であるが、これは、1091（寛治5）6月 義家の郎党藤原実清と義綱の郎党藤原則清、河内国の所領の領有権を争いから、源義家・源義綱が兵を構える事態となり、京が騒然としたことに関する当時内大臣・藤原師通の日記『後二条師通記』と、鎌倉時代後期に、それまでの諸日記を編纂した『百錬抄』（ひゃくれんしょう）に見える記事である。
sen.e: Next, there were the 'Prohibition Order for Yoshiie to enter his army into Kyoto' and 'Prohibition for Yoshiie to accept Land donations,' but these were articles derived from the diaries of Nai-daijin (the Minister of the Center, ranked below U-daijin) FUJIWARA no Moromichi, "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" and the edited collection of diaries, "Hyakuren-sho" written in the late Kamakura era, concerning Yoshiie's roto FUJIWARA no Sanekiyo and Yoshitsuna's roto FUJIWARA no Norikiyo who mobilized the army over the issue of estate right and disturbed Kyoto.

Finally, there were the 'Ban on Yoshiie bringing his army into Kyoto' and the 'Ban on Yoshiie accepting land donations,' knowledge of which comes from entries in "Gonijo Moromichi Ki," the diaries of Nai-daijin (the Minister of the Center, ranked below U-daijin) FUJIWARA no Moromichi, and the edited collection of diaries, "Hyakuren-sho," written in the late Kamakura era, concerning events in June 1091, when Kyoto was in uproar over the mobilization of Yoshiie and Yoshitsune's troops following the territorial dispute between their retainers, FUJIWARA no Sanekiyo and FUJIWARA no Norikiyo.

sen.j: この件は、安田元久も『百錬抄』には疑いを拭いきれないようで、1974年の『日本の歴史(7) 院政と平家』の中で「もし『百錬抄』にいう措置がとられたのであれば、それは左大臣俊房以下の公卿たちが、関白師実とともにとった処置であって、上皇の意志からでたものではなかったことになる。
sen.e: Even Motohisa YASUDA could not erase the doubt on "Hyakuren-sho" and noted in "Nihon no Rekishi, Vol. 7, Insei and the Taira Family" (A history of Japan, Vol. 7, The Government by a Retired Emperor and the Taira Family), 'if such treatment was made in "Hyakuren-sho," then it must have been performed by Kanpaku Morozane kugyo below Sa-daijin (the senior chief of an Imperial Japanese Council of State, ranked above U-daijin) Toshifusa, and it becomes in the way that it was not from the will of the retired emperor.'

Motohisa YASUDA could not erase the doubt over the "Hyakuren-sho" and noted in "Nihon no Rekishi, Vol. 7, Insei to Taira " (A history of Japan, Vol. 7, The Cloistered Government and the Taira Family), 'if the measures mentioned in "Hyakuren-sho" were carried out, it must have been by nobles below Sa-daijin (the senior chief of an Imperial Japanese Council of State, ranked above U-daijin) Toshifusa, in collusion with Kanpaku Morozane and did not reflect the will of the emperor.'

sen.j: 関白藤原師実は『後二条師通記』の藤原師通の父であり、藤原師通はその陣定に内大臣として出席しており、当時の公卿の日記の書き方から『後二条師通記』寛治5年6月12日条はその翌朝に書かれたものと推察できほぼリアルタイムとみなしてよい。
sen.e: Kanpaku FUJIWARA no Morozane was the father of FUJIWARA no Moromichi who wrote "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" and Moromichi attended jin-no-sadame (political debate made during Heian period) as Nai-daijin, and assuming by the way kugyo wrote his diary, "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" (dated June 12, 1091), it was probably written on the following morning and can be considered as real-time event.

Kanpaku FUJIWARA no Morozane was the father of "Gonijo Moromichi Ki" author FUJIWARA no Moromichi, who attended jin-no-sadame (government councils during Heian period) as Nai-daijin and, as the Kugyo nobles usually did, probably wrote the entry dated June 12, 1091 the following morning and, as such, it can be considered accurate.

sen.e: If such treatment mentioned in "Hyakuren-sho" was made, Kanpaku must have intervened after the will of Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa (after hearing the report from Sa-daijin) was told to the debating Kugyo, but it seemed unnatural by looking at how the politics proceeded at that time.

sen.e: The armor which 2 years old Yoshiie carried, "Genta ga Ubuginu" (the baby clothes of Genta) and the katana (Japanese sword) called "Hige kiri" (beard cutter) that was named for cutting off the head with the beard of several thousand enemies captured alive, became the family treasure passed down the Kawachi Genji clan heir, and there is an anecdote in "Heiji Monogatari" (The Tale of Heiji) that Yoritomo MINAMOTO used it in Heiji-no-Ran (Heiji Rebellion).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代中期の説話集『古今著聞集』には前九年の役の後、捕虜となったのち、家来とした（事実ではないが）安部宗任との話がいくつかあり、射芸に秀で、意味もなく動物を殺そうとしない優しさ、更に射た矢を取ってきたかつての敵・安部宗任に背中を向け、背負った矢入れに入れさせた剛胆さ、更には神通力まで備えた超人的な武士として描かれている。
sen.e: The collection of tales, "Kokon chomon shu" (Collected Stories of Ancient and Modern Times) written in the mid-Kamakura period, mentioned several conversation with ABE no Muneto, who was captured after the Earlier Nine Years' War and became the servant (not based on truth), and portrayed Yoshiie as a supernatural warrior who excelled in archery, was kind not to unnecessarily kill animals, and was bold in the way that he turned to his back to his one-time enemy, ABE no Muneto, and let him insert arrows into the arrow holder.

The collection of tales, "Kokon chomon shu" (Collected Stories of Ancient and Modern Times), written in the mid-Kamakura period, mentioned several conversations with ABE no Muneto, who was captured after the Earlier Nine Years' War and became a servant (though this was not true), that portrayed Yoshiie as a supernatural warrior who excelled in archery, was kind to not unnecessarily kill animals, and was bold in the way that he turned to his back to his one-time enemy, ABE no Muneto, and let him insert arrows into the arrow holder.

sen.j: 後三年の役が私戦とされて恩賞が出なかったため、義家は河内国石川荘の自分の私財を投じて部下の将士に報奨を与え、武家の棟梁としての信望を高めたといわれる。
sen.e: He supposedly increased his popularity as a warrior for casting aside his private property to award his generals when he himself was not rewarded for the Late Three Years' War being considered as a private war.

sen.j: 後世では、東国における武門の習いは義家が整備したといわれ、その名声は武門の棟梁としての血脈としての評価を一層高めることとなったというのは、主に南北朝時代の末に、義家の子孫である足利幕府の正統性をうたう為に書かれた『源威集』にある「諸家輩、源家将軍ヲ代々仁王ト奉仰ハ此故也」からの派生。
sen.e: Later generations claimed that, the way of bushi in Eastern Japan was established by Yoshiie, and increased the reputation as the bloodline of the chief of the bushi perhaps due to "Geni-shu" written to legitimize the Ashikaga shogunate created by the descendant of Yoshiie during the end of the Nanboku period (the period of Northern and Southern Court).

sen.e: The story handed down the Ashikaga clan is the letter written by Hachiman-dono (Lord Hachiman (Yoshiie)), "the son of seven generation after me must conquer entire Japan in place of me."

sen.j: 義家から七代目にあたる足利家時は、自分の代では達成できないため、三代後の子孫に天下を取らせよと祈願し、願文を残して自害したと『難太平記』にある。
sen.e: "Nan-taihei-ki" mentioned that the Ietoki Ashikaga, who was seventh generation son since Yoshii, could not achieve it during his lifetime, so he wished three generation after him to conquer Japan in a letter and committed suicide.

The "Nan-taihei-ki" mentioned that Ietoki ASHIKAGA, who was the seventh generation son after Yoshiie, could not achieve it during his lifetime, so, in a letter, he wished the third generation after him would conquer Japan and then committed suicide.
sen.cmt: ASHIKAGA大文字にしました。Yoshiieのe補足。

sen.j: 「敵」とは安倍貞任で、衣川関を捨てて敗走する安倍貞任を追う源義家が、矢を番えながら下の句を歌いかけると、貞任は即座にその上の句を返したので、義家は感じいって「武士の情け」と、矢を放つのを止めたという話。
sen.e: It was the tale where Minamoto no Yoshiie chased after the "enemy," Sadato ABE, who abandoned and escaped from Koromogawa Seki (castle) and called out the lower line while aiming the arrow, to which, Sadato immediately shot back the top line of the song, so Yoshiie didn't shoot him due to the "sympathy of bushi (warrior)."

sen.e: Yoritomo MINAMOTO who established the Kamakura bakufu is the son of Yoshitomo MINAMOTO, who is the great-great-grandson of Yoshiie.

sen.e: Takuji ASHIKAGA (MINAMOTO no Takuji), who established Muromachi bakufu is the descendant of the second son of the third son of Yoshiie, Yoshiyasu ASHIKAGA (MINAMOTO no Yoshiyasu).
